title: Frequently Asked Questions About the Biden Administration’s Vaccine Mandate
content: We’re answering your questions about the new OSHA rules for employers with 100 or more workers. This F.A.Q. was last updated at 3:30 p.m.

title: How Tyson Foods Got 60,500 Workers to Get the Coronavirus Vaccine Quickly
content: The meatpacking giant, which was criticized for failing to do enough to protect its workers from Covid-19 last year, has become a leader on corporate mandates.

more_info.byline: By Lauren Hirsch and Michael Corkery
org_facet: Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union
United Food and Commercial Workers Union

title: Google Wants to Work With the Pentagon Again, Despite Employee Concerns
content: Three years ago, the company walked away from a Defense Department project after employees objected to it. Now the company is working on a new proposal for the Pentagon.

more_info.byline: By Daisuke Wakabayashi and Kate Conger
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces

title: Inflation Bonds Are Getting a Big Rate Bump
content: The rise in prices has affected not only consumer goods but some government savings bonds, and it could benefit some investors looking for safe spaces for their money.

title: Fed Takes First Step Toward End of Pandemic Measures
content: The Federal Reserve is dealing with high inflation at a time when millions of workers remain on the job market’s sidelines. Wednesday’s announcement that it will slow bond purchases is a step toward more normal monetary policy.

title: In a ‘Workers Economy,’ Who Really Holds the Cards?
content: Some people are resigning. Some are sitting on the sidelines awaiting a prime gig. Others are flexing their muscles — requesting raises, or remote options — while still clocking in.

title: Smartmatic Sues Newsmax and One America News Network, Claiming Defamation
content: Smartmatic, an election technology company that faced baseless accusations of rigging the 2020 election, has filed a similar lawsuit against Fox News.

more_info.byline: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Michael M. Grynbaum

title: A Sinking Student Housing Empire
content: An ambitious property management company that pitches upscale off-campus apartments across the country has left tenants and investors stewing.

des_facet: Private Placements (Non-Public Offerings) and Mini IPOs

title: Uber lost $2.4 billion, thanks largely to Didi investment.
content: The quarter was otherwise upbeat, as business continued to rebound.

title: Pamela McCorduck, Historian of Artificial Intelligence, Dies at 80
content: She interviewed many of the scientists who were at the heart of the field through the end of the 1970s, and she compiled a groundbreaking history of its early years.

des_facet: Machines Who Think: A Personal Inquiry into the History and Prospects of Artificial Intelligence (Book)

title: What Red Flags? Elizabeth Holmes Trial Exposes Investors’ Carelessness
content: Start-up investors have often suspended skepticism while chasing a hot deal. The trial of Ms. Holmes, the founder of Theranos, has put that behavior under the spotlight.

title: With Climate Pledges, Some Wall Street Titans Warn of Rising Prices
content: Leaders of some of the world’s biggest financial firms say that the rush to transition to clean energy could have unintended consequences for the global economy.

title: Google’s parent launches a company dedicated to drug discovery.
content: Isomorphic Labs is a spinoff of the London-based artificial intelligence lab DeepMind.

title: Blue Origin Loses Legal Fight Over SpaceX’s NASA Moon Contract
content: A federal judge rejected the argument by Jeff Bezos’ rocket company that NASA unfairly awarded a lunar lander contract to Elon Musk’s firm.

title: Britain Becomes First to Authorize an Antiviral Pill for Covid-19
content: The authorization of Merck’s easy-to-use Covid treatment, molnupiravir, is a step toward taming the pandemic.

more_info.byline: By Rebecca Robbins, Aina J. Khan and Megan Specia

title: The U.S. trade deficit rose as a surge of imports bogged down the supply chain.
content: The trade deficit in September climbed to $80.9 billion, a record. Imports rose slightly, while exports fell.

title: We want to hear your questions about the new federal vaccine mandate.
content: The new guidance will cover 84 million workers, who will be required to be fully vaccinated or undergo weekly testing.

title: The Biden administration sets a Jan. 4 vaccination deadline for private sector workers.
content: The new guidance will cover 84 million workers, who will be required to be fully vaccinated or undergo weekly testing.

title: The Bank of England edges closer to raising interest rates, but holds steady.
content: Britain’s central bank said it would wait for more data on the labor market even as inflation is expected to climb to about 5 percent.

title: Behind Tyson’s Risky Bet on a Vaccine Mandate
content: The meatpacking giant took the lead on corporate vaccination rules despite uncertainty on how employees would react.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: OPEC and Russia won’t expand oil output faster, in a rebuff to President Biden.
content: Big oil producers decided to stick with a scheduled increase, rejecting calls for a bigger jump in production.

org_facet: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
per_facet: Abdulaziz bin Salman, Prince of Saudi Arabia

title: The Price of Living in ‘Paradise’ Is Higher Than Ever
content: Land and homes in Hawaii, never inexpensive, are more in demand in these days of remote working — as in remote from the U.S. mainland.

title: The U.S. Is Reopening. Here’s What Travelers Need to Know About Testing, Boosters and More.
content: Millions of travelers are expected to hit the skies and the road this holiday season. They will likely to have questions about the new regulations, which start Nov. 8.

title: Do Generations Matter? Well, Maybe.
content: Emma Goldberg recently wrote about the tension between Gen Z employees and millennial bosses. The article sparked spirited — and sometimes, heated — debate online. Here, she explores the need to categorize ourselves into generations.

title: Deere says it won’t resume talks after striking workers reject an agreement.
content: It was the second contract proposal to be voted down by union members at the farm machinery company.

title: What Jerome Powell Didn’t Do: Lay the Groundwork for Higher Rates
content: He said high inflation was mostly a result of pandemic effects like supply network disruptions, a problem he thinks the Fed can’t fix.

title: The New York Sun, a defunct newspaper, plans a comeback after a sale.
content: Seth Lipsky sold the publication to Dovid Efune, the former top editor of The Algemeiner. Mr. Lipsky will remain the top editor, and Mr. Efune will be publisher and chairman.

title: European Steel Plan Shows Biden’s Bid to Merge Climate and Trade Policy
content: A potential agreement on steel trade provides the clearest look yet at how the Biden administration plans to implement a trade policy that is both protectionist and progressive

title: U.S. Blacklists Israeli Firm NSO Group Over Spyware
content: The ban is the strongest step an American president has taken to curb abuses in the global market for spyware.

more_info.byline: By David E. Sanger, Nicole Perlroth, Ana Swanson and Ronen Bergman

title: Central banks around the world are dialing back their pandemic-era support.
content: The Federal Reserve, the Bank of England and the Reserve Bank of Australia are among several central banks pulling back support as inflation jumps.

more_info.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Eshe Nelson

title: Meet the new meme stocks? Shares of Avis and Bed Bath & Beyond soar.
content: The moves appeared linked to several factors, including positive corporate announcements, a surge in interest from retail investors and the squeezing of short sellers.

title: New Funding Offshoot Expands Grants to Arts Groups in the Southeast
content: As part of the Southern Cultural Treasures program, the Ford Foundation and an Atlanta nonprofit will funnel aid to arts groups led by people of color in that region.
